verses.text: At that time, says the LORD, the bones of the kings of Judah, the bones of its officials, the bones of the priests, the bones of the prophets, and the bones of the inhabitants of Jerusalem will be brought out of their graves.
verses.comment: The Lord warns of judgment even against the honored dead, a sign of utter disgrace. Disinterment showed public shame (see Amos 2:1).

verses.text: They will be spread out before the sun, and the moon, and all the host of heaven, whom they have loved, served, followed, sought, and worshiped. They will not be gathered or buried; they will be as dung on the face of the earth.
verses.comment: Their idolatry is exposed; the celestial objects they worshiped become witnesses to their shameful fate (cf. Deut 4:19).

verses.text: Death will be preferred to life by all the remnant that remains of this evil family, in all the places where I have driven them, says the LORD of armies.
verses.comment: The horror of judgment is so great that exile survivors will long for death—a reversal of the blessing of life (see Deut. 30:19).

verses.text: You shall say to them: Thus says the LORD, ‘Do people fall and not get up again? If someone turns away, do they not return?’
verses.comment: God appeals to human logic: just as one who falls rises again, so should Israel return from sin. Implied is the expectation of true repentance.

verses.text: Why then has this people, Jerusalem, turned away with an endless backsliding? They cling to deceit; they refuse to return.
verses.comment: Persistent unrepentance shows not simple failure but hardened hearts embracing deception. Sin develops into pattern and habit.

verses.text: I have paid attention and listened, but they do not speak honestly; no one repents of his evil, saying, ‘What have I done?’ Each one runs his own course like a horse rushing into battle.
verses.comment: Lack of self-examination blocks repentance. Errant zeal is highlighted—the people are passionate in their wrongdoing (cf. Rev 9:21).

verses.text: Even the stork in the sky knows her seasons; and the dove, the swift, and the swallow observe their time of coming. But my people do not know the judgment of the LORD.
verses.comment: Creation is wiser than the people—migratory birds instinctively respond to seasons, while Israel ignores God's timing and judgment.

verses.text: How can you say, ‘We are wise, and the law of the LORD is with us’? But behold, the lying pen of the scribes has made it into a lie.
verses.comment: Corruption of teaching is serious: outward confidence in the law is empty if its interpretation is twisted (cf. Matt 23:2-3).

verses.text: The wise men shall be put to shame; they will be dismayed and captured. Behold, they have rejected the word of the LORD, so what wisdom is in them?
verses.comment: True wisdom cannot exist apart from obedience to God. Rejecting His word exposes leaders to shame and destruction.

verses.text: Therefore I will give their wives to others, and their fields to those who will possess them. For from the least to the greatest, all are greedy for unjust gain; from prophet to priest, every one deals falsely.
verses.comment: Divine retribution follows communal corruption. Even religious leaders are not exempt from judgment; their greed brings loss.

verses.text: They have healed the wound of my people lightly, saying, ‘Peace, peace,’ when there is no peace.
verses.comment: False prophets offer superficial comfort. Sin's seriousness cannot be ignored with mere words. True peace requires true healing—hinting at a need for mediators who effect real reconciliation.

verses.text: Were they ashamed when they committed abomination? No, they were not at all ashamed; they did not even know how to blush. So they shall fall among the fallen; at the time of their punishment they shall stumble, says the LORD.
verses.comment: Lack of shame reveals a conscience seared by persistent sin (cf. Ps. 36:1-2). Shame is meant to lead to repentance and confession.

verses.text: I will surely consume them, says the LORD. No grapes shall be on the vine, nor figs on the fig tree, and even the leaves will wither. What I have given them will pass away from them.
verses.comment: Fruitless fig and vine symbolize the people's spiritual sterility—echoing Jesus' cursing of the fig tree (Matt 21:19), a symbol of coming judgment.

verses.text: Why do we sit still? Assemble! Let us go into the fortified cities and perish there. For the LORD our God has doomed us to perish, and has given us poisoned water to drink, because we have sinned against the LORD.
verses.comment: The bitterness of judgment recalls the 'waters of bitterness' (see Num. 5:23-24); sin separates from God's protection, leaving only judgment.

verses.text: We hoped for peace, but no good came; for a time of healing, but behold, terror.
verses.comment: The absence of healing and peace highlights the need for a redeemer to bring true restoration—a theme fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: The snorting of enemy horses is heard from Dan; at the sound of their neighing the whole land quakes. They come and devour the land and all that fills it, the city and those who dwell in it.
verses.comment: Dan, a territory in the north, symbolizes the direction of invasion; enemy armies signify God's instrument of chastening (see Jer. 4:15).

verses.text: For behold, I am sending among you serpents, adders that cannot be charmed, and they shall bite you, says the LORD.
verses.comment: The serpents recall God's judgment in the wilderness (Num. 21:6). This points to the seriousness of rebellion, as well as the need for spiritual remedies prefigured in later salvation themes.

verses.text: My comfort in sorrow is gone; my heart is faint within me.
verses.comment: The prophet shares God's grief—revealing divine compassion even in judgment (cf. Ps. 22:14; see also Christ's sorrow over Jerusalem, Matt. 23:37).

verses.text: Listen! The cry of the daughter of my people from a land far away: 'Is the LORD not in Zion? Is her King not in her?' 'Why have they provoked me to anger with their carved images and with foreign idols?'
verses.comment: Zion's King (the LORD) distances Himself due to idolatry, pointing ahead to the need for both a true King and a pure worship in the one appointed place.

verses.text: The harvest is past, the summer is ended, and we are not saved.
verses.comment: Missed opportunities for repentance result in unredeemed judgment—this phrase is sometimes seen as a lament for those delaying to heed God's call.

verses.text: For the wound of the daughter of my people I am wounded; I mourn, and horror has taken hold of me.
verses.comment: The prophet grieves with the people, foreshadowing the suffering servant's compassion (see Isa. 53; Matt. 23:37).

verses.text: Is there no balm in Gilead? Is there no physician there? Why then has not the health of the daughter of my people been restored?
verses.comment: Gilead was famous for healing balm, yet their spiritual wound remains. Points to the need for a true Physician (cf. Christ as healer—1 Cor. 1:30). Healing comes through the means appointed by God.
